choices.text: Spontaneous
Blunt trauma to chest
Instrumental
Penetrating trauma to chest

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe chest pain and difficulty swallowing. A CT scan with water soluble contrast reveals an esophageal perforation. What is the most common etiology of esophageal perforation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Instrumental

 

Option C:

 

Instrumental - upper GI endoscopy like dilatation, stenting


This is the most common etiology for esophageal perforation. Iatrogenic perforation may occur secondary to endoscopic procedures, such as dilatation for strictures or achalasia or during stenting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Spontaneous. Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, is a serious condition but not the most common cause. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis, which leads to a sudden increase in esophageal pressure and typically results in perforation of the lower esophagus.

 

Option B: Blunt trauma to the chest. Blunt trauma can cause esophageal perforation; however, it is less common than iatrogenic causes related to medical procedures.

 

Option D: Penetrating trauma to chest. Penetrating trauma is another possible cause of esophageal injury, but again, it is not as common as iatrogenic causes.

 

Educational Objective:


The most common cause of esophageal perforation is iatrogenic injury during instrumental procedures such as upper GI endoscopy, dilatation, and stenting.

 

  • Iatrogenic perforation secondary to endoscopic procedures such as dilatation of strictures or achalasia is the most common cause.
  • Esophageal perforation can occur due to instrumental procedures such as upper GI endoscopy, dilatation, and stenting.
  • Spontaneous esophageal perforation, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, can occur when vomiting against a closed glottis, resulting in a massive increase in esophageal pressure and typically perforating the lower esophagus over the left pleura.
  • CT with water-soluble contrast is the ideal imaging modality to diagnose esophageal perforation.
  • Treatment options for esophageal perforation include conservative management for small perforations and surgery for septic load (Boerhaave syndrome), unstable mediastinitis, or intra-abdominal esophageal perforation.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1127

choices.text: Cervical
Endoscope induced
Spontaneous
Malignant perforation

questions.text: Which type of esophageal perforation requires urgent surgical exploration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous

 

Option C:

 

Spontaneous: Spontaneous esophageal perforation, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, can occur due to a sudden increase in intra-esophageal pressure, usually associated with vomiting. This type of perforation is typically large and carries a high septic load and requires urgent surgical exploration.

 

Esophageal perforation is a rare but serious complication that requires prompt diagnosis and management. The choice of treatment depends on the location, size, and severity of the perforation. In general, small perforations can be managed conservatively, while larger perforations require surgical intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cervical: Esophageal perforation in the cervical region is rare but can occur due to trauma or surgical procedures. Depending on the size and severity of the perforation, it may require urgent surgical exploration.

 

Option B. Scope induced: Esophageal perforation induced by an upper GI endoscopy, dilatation, or stenting can range from small mucosal tears to full-thickness perforations. The size and extent of the perforation will determine the treatment approach. Small perforations may be managed conservatively, while larger perforations may require surgical exploration.

 

Option D.  Oesophageal cancer can perforate, and the prognosis is usually poor since it reflects the underlying advanced disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Urgent surgical exploration is most commonly required for spontaneous esophageal perforations, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, due to the typically large rupture and associated high septic load. It can occur when vomiting against a closed glottis, resulting in a massive increase in esophageal pressure and typically perforating the lower esophagus over the left pleura.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1128.

choices.text: Acid poisons
Alkali poisons
Both acid and alkali poisons cause the same extent of damage
Caustic injury does not cause tissue damage

questions.text: Which type of caustic injury to esophagus causes deeper tissue damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkali poisons

 

Option B:

 

Alkali poisons cause liquefactive necrosis, which results in deeper tissue damage than acid poisons.

 

Caustic injury is a serious condition caused by the ingestion of substances that are toxic to the body, such as acid or alkali poisons. It is most common in children or people with psychiatric illnesses who consume poisons.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acid poisons cause coagulative necrosis, which results in superficial tissue damage. The extent of trauma is generally less than that caused by alkali poisons.

 

Option C. Acid and alkali poisons cause different types of tissue damage, with alkali poisons causing deeper damage than acid poisons.

 

Option D. Caustic injury always causes tissue damage and can lead to scarring and strictures in the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is a premalignant condition for esophageal carcinoma.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Alkali poisons cause deeper tissue damage than acid poisons.

 

Educational Objective:


Alkali poisons cause deeper tissue damage to the esophagus compared to acid poisons due to their mechanism of causing liquefactive necrosis, which allows for deeper penetration and more extensive injury.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1129-30

choices.text: Food bolus
Fish Bone
Battery
Coin

questions.text: A 5-year-old child accidentally swallowed a foreign object while playing. What is the most dangerous foreign object that a child can swallow?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battery

 

Option C:

 

A battery, especially a button battery, is extremely dangerous when ingested because it can lead to electrical discharge or chemical leakage, causing tissue burns, necrosis, and potential perforation of the esophagus or other organs. This is an emergency situation that requires prompt removal.

 

When evaluating the danger of foreign objects swallowed by children, it is critical to assess the potential for harm based on the object's characteristics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Food bolus. A food bolus can cause obstruction but is typically not as dangerous as other objects because it often softens and passes through the gastrointestinal tract or can be removed endoscopically without causing significant damage.

 

Option B: Fish Bone. A fish bone can be sharp and potentially puncture the esophagus or other parts of the gastrointestinal tract. However, it is generally less harmful compared to corrosive or electrically charged objects because it does not cause tissue necrosis or systemic toxicity.

 

Option D: Coin. A coin can become lodged in the esophagus, particularly at one of the natural constrictions, but it generally does not cause the same degree of tissue damage as a battery. The coin can often be retrieved endoscopically without significant complication.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The most dangerous foreign object that a child can swallow is a battery due to the risk of electrical discharge, leakage of caustic substances, and the potential for rapid tissue damage and necrosis.

 

  • Swallowing a foreign object can be a serious medical emergency, especially in children. The most common foreign objects that are swallowed are food boluses and bones. However, the most dangerous foreign object that a child can swallow is a battery.
  • The esophagus has several constrictions where foreign objects can become lodged. The three most common locations for foreign body impaction are at the cricopharynx (15cm from the incisors), at the left bronchus crossing the esophagus (25cm from the incisors), and at the diaphragmatic pleura (40cm from the incisors).
  • The first step in managing a swallowed foreign body is to obtain a chest X-ray to determine the location of the object. If the object is in the esophagus or stomach, endoscopic retrieval may be possible. However, if the object is a battery, it must be removed as an emergency via endoscopy or colonoscopy, depending on the location of the foreign body.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1132

choices.text: Surgery to remove the obstruction
Administration of medications to relieve pain
Feeding the patient to promote weight gain
Endoscopic intervention to widen the narrowed angle

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She reports weight loss following a keto-diet in the past few months. On investigation, the small bowel appears normal, but a CECT of the abdomen reveals compression of the D3 segment of the duodenum due to narrowing of the angle of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Which of the following is the best option for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding the patient to promote weight gain

 

Option C:

 

The primary conservative treatment for SMA Syndrome is to increase the mesenteric fat pad, which separates the SMA from the aorta, thereby relieving the compression on the duodenum. This is typically achieved by nutritional support to promote weight gain.

 

In the context of SMA Syndrome, or Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome, it is essential to understand the treatment options based on the pathophysiology of the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Surgery to remove the obstruction. Surgical intervention may be considered if conservative measures fail. It is not the first line of treatment because the syndrome is often caused by a lack of mesenteric fat padding, not an actual physical obstruction that needs to be removed.

 

Option B: Administration of medications to relieve pain. While pain management is an important aspect of patient care, medications alone will not address the underlying issue of the narrowed angle between the SMA and the aorta, which is causing the duodenal compression.

 

Option D: Endoscopic intervention to widen the narrowed angle. Endoscopic intervention is not the standard treatment for SMA Syndrome because the problem is not within the duodenal lumen but rather external compression.

 

Educational Objective:


The initial treatment for SMA Syndrome is conservative, focusing on nutritional support to promote weight gain and increase the mesenteric fat pad, thereby relieving the compression of the duodenum.

 

  • SMA Syndrome, also known as Wilkie Syndrome, is a rare cause of intestinal obstruction. It occurs due to the narrowing of the angle between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and aorta, leading to compression of the third part of the duodenum (D3).

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Sudden weight loss
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Prolonged bed rest
  • Scoliosis
  • The clinical features of SMA Syndrome include colicky abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and weight loss. On investigation, the small bowel appears normal, but a CECT of the abdomen may reveal compression of the D3 segment of the duodenum due to narrowing of the angle of the SMA.
  • The initial treatment for SMA Syndrome is conservative and involves feeding the patient to promote weight gain and open the narrowed angle. This can be achieved through the placement of a naso-jejunostomy tube. If this fails, surgery may be required to bypass the duodenum and relieve the obstruction.

 

Ref: Online article: https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-11142

choices.text: Conservative management with nasogastric decompression and washout
Surgical reconstruction using Billroth II procedure
Endoscopic dilatation of the stricture
Mikulicz stricturoplasty to relieve the obstruction

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents with a complaint of non-bilious vomiting. On examination, a succussion splash is heard over abdomen. CECT reveals the presence of a pyloric stricture. Which of the following is the first step for management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conservative management with nasogastric decompression and washout

 

Option A:

 

This is the first step in the management of pyloric stricture. It provides immediate relief from symptoms by decompressing the stomach and washing out its contents, which can help alleviate vomiting and allow for a clearer assessment of the stricture. Often, this decompression may relieve the edema at pylorus and open the pyloric channel.

 

When managing a pyloric stricture, it is essential to consider the most appropriate first step to provide relief and set the stage for further treatment if necessary.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Surgical reconstruction using Billroth II procedure. The Billroth II procedure is a surgical option (gastro-jejunostomy) that is generally considered after conservative management has failed.

 

Option C: Endoscopic dilatation of the stricture. Endoscopic dilatation is a less invasive treatment option compared to surgery and can be effective in managing strictures. However, it is not the first-line treatment before attempting nasogastric decompression.

 

Option D: Mikulicz strictureplasty to relieve the obstruction. Mikulicz strictureplasty is a surgical technique used when strictures are not amenable to endoscopic dilatation. It is considered a more advanced step if other less invasive measures fail.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The first step in managing a pyloric stricture is conservative management with nasogastric decompression and washout to provide symptomatic relief

 

  • Pyloric stricture is a late complication of peptic ulcer disease, which occurs due to the fibrosis and scarring that develop when the circumferential ulcers over the stomach heal. This can lead to narrowing of the stomach or gastric outlet obstruction, which usually occurs at the first part of the duodenum.
  • Clinical features of pyloric stricture include a history of peptic ulcer disease and non-bilious vomiting.
  • The management of pyloric stricture depends on the extent and severity of the obstruction. Initial conservative management involves nasogastric decompression and washout, which can provide symptomatic relief.
  • Endoscopy can be used to confirm the presence of a stricture and to obtain a biopsy to rule out adenocarcinoma. If the stricture is benign, it can be treated with dilatation. If dilatation fails, surgery may be required to relieve the obstruction.
  • Mikulicz stricturoplasty is a surgical procedure that involves opening the pylorus horizontally and closing it vertically to relieve the obstruction. This is a preferred option when the stricture is not amenable to endoscopic dilatation. Billroth II reconstruction is another surgical option that involves removal of the pylorus and reconstruction of the gastrointestinal tract to improve gastric emptying.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1169

choices.text: Serum lipase
USG abdomen
X ray upper abdomen erect
CECT abdomen angiogram

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of chronic atrial fibrillation presents with acute abdominal pain and PR bleed. Abdominal examination revealed vague tenderness and diminished bowel sounds. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT abdomen angiogram

 

Option D:

 

A Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) of the abdomen with angiogram is the investigation of choice for suspected mesenteric ischemia. It can provide detailed images of the blood vessels supplying the intestines and can help identify blockages, assess the extent of bowel involvement, and guide further management.

 

  • The scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. Mesenteric ischemia occurs when the blood supply to the bowel is obstructed.
  • This can be acute or chronic, and most of the bowel is supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).
  • Acute mesenteric ischemia may be due to embolism and can present with acute abdominal pain, no bowel sounds, ischemia of the bowel, and PR bleed. On palpation, signs are very few.

 

When considering the appropriate step in the investigation for a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of mesenteric ischemia, it is crucial to choose a diagnostic tool that will provide rapid and clear results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Serum lipase. While serum lipase can be useful in diagnosing pancreatitis, it would not be the most helpful initial test for a patient suspected of having mesenteric ischemia.

 

Option B: USG abdomen. An ultrasound of the abdomen can be useful for assessing many abdominal conditions, but it may not be the best choice for evaluating blood flow or identifying mesenteric ischemia, especially in an acute setting.

 

Option C: X-ray upper abdomen erect. An erect abdominal X-ray can show signs of bowel obstruction or free air under the diaphragm in cases of perforation but is not the most sensitive or specific test for mesenteric ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with suspected acute mesenteric ischemia, particularly in the context of chronic atrial fibrillation, the next best investigation is a CECT abdomen angiogram.

 

  • SMA emboli may be carried from the left atrium in atrial fibrillation, the left ventricle after mural myocardial infarction, vegetations on mitral and aortic valves associated with endocarditis or an atheromatous plaque from an aortic aneurysm
  • Investigation for mesenteric ischemia includes a CECT scan, which can determine whether the occlusion is acute or chronic and assess bowel viability or gangrene. Treatment for mesenteric ischemia depends on the extent and severity of the obstruction. Conservative management with antibiotics and bowel rest may be used in some cases.
  • For acute occlusion, mesenteric vascular intervention is the preferred treatment. If there is evidence of gangrene, laparotomy and bowel resection may be required.
  • Chronic mesenteric ischemia typically presents with mesenteric angina (central abdominal pain) and diarrhoea. A CECT angiogram can reveal atherosclerosis of the mesentery. Treatment for chronic mesenteric ischemia involves mesenteric angioplasty bypass.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1312-1313

choices.text: Sepsis control and skin care, TPN, CECT, and planned repair
Antibiotics, enteral nutrition, MRI, and surgical intervention
Conservative management, low-residue diet, ultrasound, and outpatient follow-up
Bowel rest, antibiotics, barium enema, and observation

questions.text: What is the management protocol for enterocutaneous fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sepsis control and skin care, TPN, CECT, and planned repair

 

Option A:

 

This option follows the SNAP protocol for the management of enterocutaneous fistulas:

 

  • Sepsis control and skin care are crucial initial steps to manage infection and protect the skin around the fistula site.
  • Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) provides nutritional support, essential when the patient cannot receive adequate enteral nutrition due to the fistula.
  • Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is used for anatomical assessment to determine the fistula's path and involvement of surrounding structures.

 

Planned repair refers to the definitive surgical intervention required to correct the fistula, which is planned after the initial steps have been taken

 

 

For the management of enterocutaneous fistulas, it is important to approach the condition methodically, addressing the key aspects of the condition which are encapsulated in the SNAP protocol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Antibiotics, enteral nutrition, MRI, and surgical intervention. While antibiotics and surgical intervention may be part of the management, enteral nutrition may not be feasible with a high-output fistula, and MRI is not the standard imaging modality for this condition.

 

Option C: Conservative management, low-residue diet, ultrasound, and outpatient follow-up. Conservative management may be indicated in some cases, but this option lacks the aggressive approach often required for enterocutaneous fistulas, such as TPN and detailed imaging.

 

Option D: Bowel rest, antibiotics, barium enema, and observation. Bowel rest and observation are part of the initial management, but merely antibiotics might not be sufficient for sepsis control, and a barium enema is not typically used for fistula assessment due to the risk of extravasation and worsening sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The management protocol for enterocutaneous fistula involves sepsis control, skin care, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), anatomical delineation with a CECT scan, and planned surgical repair following the SNAP protocol.

 

  • Enterocutaneous fistula is an abnormal communication between the bowel and the skin, which can be caused by postoperative complications, Crohn's disease, GI malignancies, or radiation enteritis. The management of enterocutaneous fistula is based on the SNAP protocol.
  • Sepsis control and skin care are essential for the management of enterocutaneous fistula, along with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to provide adequate nutrition. Anatomical delineation, typically through a CECT scan, is necessary to identify the extent of the fistula and plan for repair.
  • Planned repair is the ultimate goal of management, but high-output fistulas (>500ml) may not close spontaneously, and additional interventions may be required. Conservative management, a low-residue diet, and ultrasound are not effective for managing enterocutaneous fistula, and surgical intervention is required for definitive treatment.

 

Principles of management of enterocutaneous fistulae (SNAP)

 

S - elimination of Sepsis and Skin protection

 

N - Nutrition – a period of parenteral nutrition may well be required

 

A - Anatomical assessment

 

P - definitive Planned surgery

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1315-16

choices.text: Excoriation of surrounding skin is more common than ileostomy
Loop stomas are usually done for temporary indications
Loop ileostomy is easier to construct than loop transverse colostomy
Ileostomy is spouted, whereas colostomy is flushed with the skin

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient underwent surgery for colon cancer, and a transverse colostomy was created. Which of the following complications is the patient unlikely to experience?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Excoriation of surrounding skin is more common than ileostomy

 

Option A:

 

Excoriation of the skin around the stoma is an uncommon complication due to the irritation from the stoma output, as the contents are well formed. This is more seen in ileostomy.

 

When considering the complications, a patient may face after the creation of a transverse colostomy, it's important to differentiate between common and less likely complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Temporary or defunctioning stomas are usually fashioned as loop stomas.

 

Option C: The advantage of a loop ileostomy over a loop colostomy is the ease with which the bowel can be brought to the surface.

 

Option D: An ileostomy is spouted; a colostomy is flush because the ileostomy effluent is usually liquid, whereas colostomy effluent is usually solid. The spouts permit easier drainage of the secretions.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

INTESTINAL STOMA:

 

  • It is the surgical exteriorization of a portion of the small bowel or colon. In this case, the patient underwent surgery for colon cancer, and a transverse colostomy was created. Stoma creation is indicated to protect anastomosis and for intestinal obstruction.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1313-14.

choices.text: Achalasia cardia
Plummer Vinson syndrome
Schatzki ring
Ca esophagus

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, non-smoker presented with intermittent dysphagia for the past 3 months. Barium swallow showed the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schatzki ring

 

Option C:

 

Schatzki rings are mucosal rings that occur at the squamocolumnar junction and can cause intermittent dysphagia, often for solid foods. The barium swallow image may show a thin, circumferential constriction at the lower end of the esophagus, which is suggestive of a Schatzki ring.

 

Thin circumferential ring seen in distal esophagus is Schatzki ring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Achalasia cardia. Achalasia cardia typically presents with a dilated esophagus and a "bird's beak" narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction. The absence of normal peristalsis in the body of the esophagus is also characteristic.

 

Option B: Plummer Vinson syndrome. Plummer Vinson syndrome is associated with upper esophageal webs and iron deficiency anemia. Barium swallow may show thin web-like structures in the upper esophagus.

 

Option D: Ca Esophagus. Esophageal cancer can present with various findings on a barium swallow, including irregular or nodular filling defects, luminal narrowing, and possibly evidence of tumor invasion. It does not typically present as a thin circumferential ring.

The description of the image suggests that the most likely diagnosis is a Schatzki ring, as it is characterized by a thin circumferential ring in the distal esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:


A Schatzki ring, presenting as a thin circumferential constriction at the gastroesophageal junction on a barium swallow, is the most probable diagnosis in a patient with intermittent dysphagia.

 

  • Schatzki ring is a benign condition
  • There is a concentric, fibrous thickening and narrowing of the gastro-esophageal junction (GEJ), with squamous epithelium above and columnar cells below.
  • Most common presentation - Dysphagia (if diameter < 13mm) and gastro-esophageal reflux disorder (GERD).
  • Most common site - lower third of the esophagus.
  • Treatment is endoscopic dilation with anti-reflux therapy

 

Ref: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition pg 1147

choices.text: Phytobezoar
Trichobezoar
Ca stomach
Gastric volvulus

questions.text: A young schizophrenic female presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. The surgeon notices that she has scanty hair on scalp, and on palpation of abdomen there is crepitus in the stomach. She is likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichobezoar

 

Option B:
 

Trichobezoars are accumulations of ingested hair within the gastrointestinal tract. They are commonly associated with trichotillomania, a condition often seen in young psychiatric patients where the individual has a compulsion to pull out their own hair. The presence of scanty hair and crepitus in the stomach due to trapped air among the hair fibers is suggestive of a trichobezoar.

 

Based on the clinical presentation of a young female with psychiatric illness, abdominal pain, vomiting, and the physical examination findings of scanty scalp hair and abdominal crepitus, let’s evaluate the possible diagnoses:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Phytobezoar. Phytobezoars are composed of indigestible plant material and are typically found in patients with impaired gastric motility, often secondary to gastric surgery, and not necessarily associated with psychiatric conditions or hair ingestion.

 

Option C: Ca stomach. Gastric cancer (Ca stomach) could present with abdominal pain and vomiting but would not typically present with crepitus in the stomach or be associated with the ingestion of hair.

 

Option D: Gastric volvulus. Gastric volvulus presents with acute abdominal pain and may lead to vomiting, but it is unlikely to be associated with hair ingestion or crepitus on abdominal palpation unless there is associated gastric strangulation and perforation, which is a medical emergency.

 

The clinical picture provided most consistently aligns with a trichobezoar, given the patient's psychiatric history and the specific finding of crepitus in the stomach on palpation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In a young psychiatric patient presenting with abdominal pain, vomiting, and evidence of scanty scalp hair, along with palpable crepitus in the stomach, the likely diagnosis is a trichobezoar.

 

  • Trichobezoar (hair balls) are unusual and are virtually exclusively found in young psychiatric patients.
  • It is caused by the ingestion of hair, which remains undigested in the stomach.
  • The hair ball can lead to ulceration and gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation or obstruction.
  • The diagnosis is made easily at endoscopy.
  • Treatment consists of removal of the bezoar, which may require open surgical treatment.
  • Phytobezoars are made of vegetable matter and are found principally in patients who have gastric stasis, usually following gastric surgery.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition pg 1180

choices.text: Acute epigastric pain
Abdominal distension
Vomiting
Inability to pass Ryle’s tube

questions.text: All of these are a part of Borchardt’s triad seen in gastric volvulus except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal distension

 

Option B:

 

The correct answer, as given, is Option B, Abdominal distension, because it is not part of the classic Borchardt’s triad for gastric volvulus. The classic triad actually consists of acute epigastric pain, vomiting, and the inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

 

  • Borchardt’s triad is a feature of gastric volvulus.
  • Acute gastric volvulus can cause gastric infarction leading to GI hemorrhage, acute cardiopulmonary distress, or shock.
  • MCC of gastric volvulus - Paraesophageal hernia
  • It may be along the length/organo-axial (MC type) or along the omental attachments (mesentero-axial).
  • IOC- CECT abdomen
  • Management of gastric volvulus - Surgical treatment is required increasingly by a laparoscopic approach. If there is a hernia, the sac and its contents (usually the stomach) should be reduced. The defect in the diaphragm should be closed, if necessary, with a mesh. It is advisable to separate the stomach from the transverse colon and to perform an anterior gastropexy to fix the stomach to the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Borchardt’s triad is a classical clinical presentation associated with gastric volvulus, which is a rotation of the stomach by more than 180 degrees, creating a closed-loop obstruction that can compromise the blood supply. The triad includes the following components:

 

Option A: Acute epigastric pain. Patients typically present with sudden onset of severe epigastric pain due to the rotation of the stomach and potential compromise of its blood supply.

 

Option C: Vomiting. Vomiting or retching is a common feature due to the obstruction of the GI tract. However, in some cases of complete volvulus, vomiting may not be possible as the rotation prevents gastric emptying.

 

Option D: Inability to pass Ryle’s tube. The inability to pass a nasogastric tube (Ryle’s tube) into the stomach is due to the physical obstruction created by the volvulus, and it is a classic sign of this condition.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1180-81

Online reference https://radiopaedia.org/articles/borchardts-triad-gastric-volvulus

choices.text: Tumor size 2-3 cm
Tumor size 3-4 cm
Tumor size 4-5 cm
Tumor size 5-7 cm

questions.text: In TNM staging of Lung cancer, Stage T1c implies:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor size 2-3 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNM staging lung cancer

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 985-991

choices.text: Thymoma
Neurogenic Tumors
Paravertebral Abscess
Lymphoma

questions.text: Most common Posterior Mediastinal Mass is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurogenic Tumors

 

Option B: Neurogenic tumors, which include nerve sheath tumors (schwannomas, neurofibromas) and ganglioneuromas, are indeed the most common masses found in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thymoma is a tumor originating from the thymic tissue and is most commonly located in the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Paravertebral abscesses are collections of pus near the vertebral column. They can present as a mass in the posterior mediastinum but are not the most common.

 

Option D. Lymphomas can involve the mediastinum, but they are not the most common posterior mediastinal mass; they more frequently involve the anterior or superior mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common posterior mediastinal mass is a neurogenic tumor.

 

Types of mediastinal masses

 

 

  • MC Anterior Mediastinal Mass: Thymoma
  • MC Post Mediastinal Mass: Neuromas/Neurogenic Tumors

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 992-993

choices.text: Parathyroid Adenoma
Neuroma
Thymoma
Bronchogenic Cyst

questions.text: Masaoka staging is used to classify:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Masaoka staging system is used to classify thymoma, assessing the degree of tumor invasion to guide treatment, which commonly includes thymectomy.

 

  • This is the most common anterior mediastinal tumour, accounting for 25% of the total, and is derived from the thymus gland.
  • Thymomas vary in behaviour from benign to aggressively invasive, as classified in the Masoaka classification system used to stage thymomas and more recently the TNM classification.
  • They are often related to myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular condition that can have a high associated incidence of thymomas, and interestingly may respond to excision of the thymus gland even when the gland has no associated thymoma present.
  • The only reliable indicator of malignancy is capsular invasion.
  • Diagnosis and treatment are best achieved by complete thymectomy, which for large tumours (>5 cm)
  • Treatment - Thymectomy: Open surgery /video assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 992

choices.text: MRI Brain
CT Brain
CSF Manometry
Lumbar Puncture

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with obstructive hydrocephalus secondary to a suspected brain tumor. What is the first line investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT Brain

 

Option B: CT brain is often the first-line imaging modality in this scenario as it quickly provides images that can show the presence of hydrocephalus, mass lesions, bleeds, and cerebral edema.

 

CT is a first-line investigation to identify causes of raised ICP, including mass lesions, bleeds, cerebral oedema and hydrocephalus, and to guide treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI Brain provides detailed images of the brain's anatomy and can be useful in assessing brain tumors. However, it is not typically the first-line investigation due to the time it takes to perform and the need for sedation in young children.

 

Option C. CSF manometry is used to measure the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid but is not the first-line investigation for a brain tumor or hydrocephalus, and it can be dangerous in the presence of increased intracranial pressure due to mass effect.

 

Option D. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated as an initial investigation in the presence of raised intracranial pressure due to the risk of brain herniation; it is performed after imaging has excluded obstructive hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line investigation for a child with obstructive hydrocephalus suspected to be secondary to a brain tumor is a CT brain scan to rapidly assess for mass effect and guide further management.

 

Types of Hydrocephalus

 

1. Obstructive: masses/ tumours / infection

 

2. Non obstructive / communicating: defective absorption

 

  • Secondary to meningitis
  • Secondary to sub arachnoid haemorrhage (lining which absorbs CSF is damaged)

 

3. Excessive CSF production- very rare

 

First line Investigation - CT BRAIN: dilated ventricles, provides clue to etiology

 

  • Lumbar puncture done after CT scan: done only if it is non- obstructive.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 703

choices.text: Lateral Ventricles
3rd Ventricle
4th Ventricle
Cisterna Magna

questions.text: In a Ventriculoperitoneal Shunt Surgery, the upper end of the shunt is inserted into:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral Ventricles

 

Option A: The Lateral ventricles are the typical site for the insertion of the upper end of the shunt in ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery. This allows for the drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the dilated ventricles due to hydrocephalus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The 3rd ventricle is not a common site for shunt placement in ventriculoperitoneal shunting. It is, however, the site targeted in endoscopic third ventriculostomy, which is a different procedure.

 

Option C. The 4th ventricle is also not typically used for the insertion of the upper end of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. Access to the fourth ventricle is more complex and not necessary for routine CSF shunting.

 

Option D. The Cisterna magna is not used for the placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. It is sometimes accessed in the placement of a lumboperitoneal shunt or for certain diagnostic procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery, the upper end of the shunt is inserted into the lateral ventricles to treat hydrocephalus. The lower end is placed into the intra-peritoneal cavity, and a valve regulates the flow of CSF.

 

Treatment of hydrocephalus

 

  1. External ventricular drain
  2. Endoscopic third ventriculostomy
  3. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt
    • Upper end is put into lateral ventricles
    • Lower end into Intra peritoneal cavity
    • A shunt valve inserted between the proximal and distal catheters regulates flow through the system by opening at a predetermined pressure; the shunt valve typically incorporates a CSF reservoir, which allows for percutaneous sampling.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 705

choices.text: Lung
Liver
Kidney
Breast

questions.text: Most common tissue of origin for brain metastases is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 715

choices.text: Temporal
Parietal
Occipital
Frontal

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with personality change, gait disturbance and urinary incontinence since 2 months. A CT Brain is likely to show a mass in which lobe?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Frontal

 

Option D: The Frontal lobe is involved in a wide variety of functions, including motor skills, problem-solving, spontaneity, memory, language, initiation, judgment, impulse control, and social and sexual behavior. Disturbances in this lobe can lead to changes in personality, gait disturbance, and problems with executive functions, which can manifest as urinary incontinence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Temporal lobe is primarily involved with processing auditory information and memory. Lesions here might lead to problems with memory, understanding language, or disturbances in hearing.

 

Option B. The Parietal lobe integrates sensory information from various modalities, including spatial sense and navigation (proprioception), the main sensory receptive area for the sense of touch. Disturbances here typically affect spatial awareness and proprioception.

 

Option C. The Occipital lobe is the visual processing center of the brain. Lesions in the occipital lobe can lead to visual deficits like blindness or visual field cuts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mass in the frontal lobe of the brain can present with personality changes, gait disturbances, and urinary incontinence, correlating with the functions mediated by this area of the brain.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 714
